question: Question_04
statement:
Write down a piecewise algebraic expression for a function $f$ satisfying
all of the following criteria.

\begin{enumerate}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  $f$ is defined on the interval {[}-1,1{]}.
\item
  $f$ is discontinuous at \emph{x} = 0 and \emph{x} = 1, and continuous
  everywhere else on {[}-1,1{]}.
\item
  $f$ has a global minimum at \emph{x} = 0.
\item
  $f$ has no global or local maximum.
\end{enumerate}

Make a large sketch of the graph of $f$ as well.
sols:
As was suggested in the hint, one way to approach this problem is to
draw a function that satisfies the first criterion and then modify it to
fit each following criterion. It is worth noting that there are many,
many ways to draw a picture satisfying all 4 criteria - the solution
that follows is just one example.

Our first criterion is that the function be defined on the interval
{[}-1,1{]}. We will draw just a straight line at $y = 1$ on this
interval:

\begin{figure}[htbp]
\centering
\includegraphics[width=.5\textwidth]{ScienceMathExamResourcesCoursesMATH110April2012Question4pt1.jpg}
\caption{ScienceMathExamResourcesCoursesMATH110April2012Question4pt1.jpg}
\end{figure}

Now we add the criterion that the function be discontinuous at $x = 0$
and $x = 1$. One simple way to do this (without making the function
undefined at those points, remember part 1!) is to move the two points
at $x = 0$ and $x = 1$ to a new location, in our case, the x-axis.

\begin{figure}[htbp]
\centering
\includegraphics[width=.5\textwidth]{ScienceMathExamResourcesCoursesMATH110April2012Question4pt2.jpg}
\caption{ScienceMathExamResourcesCoursesMATH110April2012Question4pt2.jpg}
\end{figure}

Now we want $f$ to have a global minimum at $x = 0$. This is easy enough
- we'll just move our point that's now at the origin down until it is
the lowest point on the entire graph.

\begin{figure}[htbp]
\centering
\includegraphics[width=.5\textwidth]{ScienceMathExamResourcesCoursesMATH110April2012Question4pt3.jpg}
\caption{ScienceMathExamResourcesCoursesMATH110April2012Question4pt3.jpg}
\end{figure}

Finally, we can't have a local or global maximum. Right now, our
straight line is both a local and global maximum because each point on
the line is greater than or equal to its neighboring points. In order to
make sure that each point on our line has a neighbor that is greater
than itself, we will tilt the line, like so:

\begin{figure}[htbp]
\centering
\includegraphics[width=.5\textwidth]{ScienceMathExamResourcesCoursesMATH110April2012Question4pt4.jpg}
\caption{ScienceMathExamResourcesCoursesMATH110April2012Question4pt4.jpg}
\end{figure}

There are two important things to note here: first, this change has not
altered any of the previous criteria (still defined on {[}-1,1{]}, still
discontinuous at appropriate points, etc.) Second, look at the right
endpoint of the graph. Because this point is undefined, $f$ cannot have
a global or local maximum at this point, and any point on the line
cannot be a maximum either.

Thus we have drawn a function that satisfies all four criteria. We now
simply translate our picture into a piecewise function. The ``line''
will be two pieces, and each point at $x = 0$ and $x = 1$ will be
another piece each.

$f(x) = \begin{cases}
1/2x + 1/2 & -1 \leq x < 0 \\
-1/2 & x = 0 \\
1/2x + 1/2 & 0 < x < 1 \\
0 & x = 1 \\
\end{cases}$
hints:
Try drawing a graph satisfying the first criterion and then modifying it
to also satisfy the next criterion, and so on until you've used all four
criteria.
